history.content:
This is subjective and depends on the course and the professor handling the hiring. In many cases existing involvement with the course is weighted highly, but previous teaching experience is too. You can apply to tutor and TA the same course and if you don't get the TA offer you will still be considered for the tutor position.

Agreeing with the above. I would say that it's hard to say exactly which is better, but that both paths are fairly common. At least for upper division courses, transferring from being a TA as a different class is probably more common, just because there's more TAs for lower divs then there are readers for upper divs. What's more important is doing a good job of whatever job you took (so that you have a good recommendation from the instructor).

This is subjective and depends on the course and the professor handling the hiring. In many cases existing involvement with the course is weighted highly, but previous teaching experience is too. You can apply to tutor and TA the same course and if you don't get the TA offer you will still be considered for the tutor position.

Consider a student who takes 61A during his first semester, lab assists during his second semester, becomes a tutor in his third semester, and then becomes a UGSI for his fourth semester. If he's interested in getting involved with the course staff of another course he has taken (i.e. CS61C, CS 70, CS 170, CS 188, CS 189, etc.) during his fifth semester, assuming he has the grades necessary, can/should he apply to become a GSI directly? If not, should he apply to become a tutor directly? Or should he lab assist during his fourth semester first (alongside being a UGSI) so he can apply to become a tutor?

A quick followup scenario: consider two students who have taken Course A and both of them got an A in the course. Student A becomes a tutor for Course A and Student B becomes a UGSI for Course B. If they both apply to become a TA for Course A the following semester, would Student A or Student B be more preferred?

Basically, does the CS faculty in general only look for prospective TAs who have worked in the course staff before (lab assisting or tutoring or reading) or is experience in any course staff taken at equal weight?

I know exceptions exist but I want to know generally what would be advised. Thanks!
history.subject: Becoming a UGSI for existing UGSIs
